Award.AwardTitle: MARGINS: The Explosive Volcanic History of the Central Oregon Cascades: Probing the Changing State of the Neogene Cascade Arc
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction zones ? volcanically active regions where one tectonic plate is pushed beneath another ? are home to most of the Earth?s explosive volcanic eruptions. In large part this is because the magmas that are produced and erupted in subduction zones tend to be both richer in water and in silica, both of which increase the propensity for eruptions to be explosive. The Cascade margin, running from Mount Lassen in northern California to southern British Columbia is host to a number of well-known volcanoes such as Mount Hood, Mount St Helens and Mount Rainier as well as numerous other volcanic edifices, and much of the region is also heavily populated. Explosive eruptions have occurred in the recent history of the Cascades, examples include Mount St Helens in 1980 and the prehistoric eruption of Mount Mazama at Crater Lake ~7700 years ago. However, although these younger eruptions are well documented, less is known about the long-term explosive record of the Cascade subduction zone over longer timescales, and the forces that influence such explosive behavior.

This project will help establish the long-term eruptive history of the Cascades in Central Oregon over the last 15 million years, by looking at volcanic rocks preserved within the Deschutes and Simtustus Formations of central Oregon. Many examples of ash fall and ash flow deposits that result from large explosive eruptions are preserved in these sequences, and they can be used to estimate the frequency, composition, age and size of large explosive eruptions in this section of the subduction zone. This research will use a combination of approaches, including field, geochronological, geochemical and petrological studies and will enable us to study changes in eruption rate, eruption size and chemical and isotopic composition through time and to compare this to the more recent behavior of the subduction zone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided for a study of volcanic rocks associated with the Cascadia subduction zone. We studied a sequence of volcanic rocks preserved in the Deschutes Basin of Central Oregon. This includes the region broadly between the towns of Sisters, Bend, Warm Springs and Madras. Because this region lies to the east of the modern Cascade volcanoes we were able to study a stage of volcanic activity in the Cascades that is older than the current batch of volcanoes and related to an older phase of volcanic activity. This study helps us understand the history of the Cascade volcanoes and to investigate how the volcanic activity associated with subduction zones can vary through time.

The research shows that although the modern Cascade volcanoes tend to be dominated by relatively small volcanic eruptions and by eruptions that are less explosive, this has not always been the case. The older phase of volcanism that we studied (dating from about 5 million years ago) was quite different than the modern Cascades. It included a large number (at least 14) of major explosive eruptions within a short interval (about 500,000 years) starting about 5.5 million years ago. These eruptions were much larger than most eruptions that have occurred in the Cascades since this time, and also involved more silica-rich magma and as a result included much more explosive types of volcanic activity. We believe that this unique period is related to the establishment of the Cascade volcanoes in a new position between 5-8 milliono years ago, possibly also in association with extension along parts of the subduction zone.

We developed new statistical techniques to enable geologists to correlate volcanic rock units from different locations using their chemical composition. We also develop other techaniques that let us estimate the volume of material erupted by large explosive volcanic eruptions.

Our work also allowed us to assist important efforts to communicate science, and in particular volcano science to the public through discussion with the media, visits to school and on campus demonstrations. Our results were also published in scientific journals and in student theses archived at Oregon State University.
